# This Python 3 environment comes with many helpful analytics libraries installed
# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
import plotly.express as px
import plotly.graph_objs as go
import plotly.offline as py

import warnings
warnings.simplefilter(action='ignore', category=FutureWarning)

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# You can write up to 20GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All" 
# You can also write temporary files to /kaggle/temp/, but they won't be saved outside of the current session

#https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38516481/trying-to-remove-commas-and-dollars-signs-with-pandas-in-python

df['TOTAL GROSS'] = df['TOTAL GROSS'].str.replace(',', '')
df['TOTAL GROSS'] = df['TOTAL GROSS'].str.replace('$', '')
df['TOTAL GROSS'] = df['TOTAL GROSS'].astype(int)
df['AVERAGE GROSS'] = df['AVERAGE GROSS'].str.replace(',', '')
df['AVERAGE GROSS'] = df['AVERAGE GROSS'].str.replace('$', '')
df['AVERAGE GROSS'] = df['AVERAGE GROSS'].astype(int)

source.7293cd61:
#Remove commas to avoid errors ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10
#ValueError on the snippet below: invalid literal for int() with base 10: '17.02'


#Code by Sohom Majumder https://www.kaggle.com/sohommajumder21/statistical-tests-for-understanding-life-value/comments

df['MARKET SHARE']=df['MARKET SHARE'].str.replace(',', '')
df['MARKET SHARE'] = pd.to_numeric(df['MARKET SHARE'], errors = 'coerce')
source.dcb1acd8:

df['MARKET SHARE'] = [int(x) for x in df['MARKET SHARE'].values]

source.8caac35f:
#Code by https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/python-binomial-distribution/

from scipy.stats import binom
# setting the values
# of n and p
n = 10
p = 0.8
# defining the list of r values
r_values = list(range(n + 1))
# obtaining the mean and variance 
mean, var = binom.stats(n, p)
# list of pmf values
dist = [binom.pmf(r, n, p) for r in r_values ]
# printing the table
print("r\tp(r)")
for i in range(n + 1):
    print(str(r_values[i]) + "\t" + str(dist[i]))
# printing mean and variance
print("mean = "+str(mean))
print("variance = "+str(var))
source.24b185f8:
#Code by https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/python-binomial-distribution/

from scipy.stats import binom
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
# setting the values
# of n and p
n = 10
p = 0.8
# defining list of r values
r_values = list(range(n + 1))
# list of pmf values
dist = [binom.pmf(r, n, p) for r in r_values ]
# plotting the graph 
plt.bar(r_values, dist)
plt.show()

from wordcloud import WordCloud
from wordcloud import STOPWORDS
stopwords = set(STOPWORDS)
wordcloud = WordCloud(background_color = 'Blue',
                      height =2000,
                      width = 2000
                     ).generate(str(df["DISTRIBUTORS"]))
plt.rcParams['figure.figsize'] = (12,12)
plt.axis("off")
plt.imshow(wordcloud)
plt.title("Holywood Theatrical distributors")
plt.show()

source.7a763958:
What is Python Probability Distribution

A probability distribution is a function under probability theory and statistics- one that gives us how probable different outcomes are in an experiment. It describes events in terms of their probabilities; this is out of all possible outcomes. Let’s take the probability distribution of a fair coin toss. Here, heads take a value of X=0.5 and tails gets X=0.5 too. Two classes of such a distribution are discrete and continuous. The former represented by a probability mass function and the latter by a probability density function. https://data-flair.training/blogs/python-probability-distributions/
